title: Can any set(say) A be a proper subset of any other set (say) B if they are not equal? So like every two equal sets cannot be a proper subset to one another? - Quora

response.answer_text: What am I reading? You literally defined them yourself… A proper subset cannot be equal to a set it is derived from, otherwise it wouldn’t be a proper subset, it would just be a subset. A proper subset is defined as a set; for example {3,5}; that is part, not whole, of another set; for example {6,3,5,7,2} Similarly, a subset can be the set itself, it doesn’t have to be just a part, but it can be… only a proper subset cannot be the original set. Now then… to answer your question literally… Is it possible? yes is it always? No Because according to the question, you are assuming {2,1} =/= {4,7} therefore {2,1} c {4,7} which is not true at all. (I can’t remember which sign is which for proper subset vs subset, so if I’m wrong in the sign, I meant “subset”) Lastly, let me define “equal” to you, because you might be confused… when two sets are equal, they have exactly the same items in its set. Order does not matter in a set, so {3,6,4} = {4,3,6} equality denotes subsets… but not proper subsets. If I could shove some English down your throat too, there’s a reason the word “proper” is in the name.
